event.title: Open source companies 101 - Emily Omier, Positioning Consultant, Emily Omier Consulting
event.abstract: What exactly is an open source company? What are the fundamental principles of building an open source company? It’s surprisingly common for founders of open source companies to lose sight of the foundational principles of building open source companies and of the challenges and opportunities that all open source companies share. In this talk, Emily Omier will provide her definition of an open source company and the foundations that the leads of open source companies should build on — as well as give examples of how getting the foundations right leads to better business outcomes.

event.title: To know your VC, you must become a VC - Tanya Dadasheva,CEO & Co-founder, Ainekko
event.abstract: Spending 8 years in a deep tech VC fund with quite a few OSS investments, I can strongly say "classical VCs ruin everything" when it comes to open source. Thing is, VCs invest in companies, in products, in scaling... The list goes on, but it does not include community, effects on the industry or motivating developers. When you consider a system that takes all of this into account it's a way bigger picture then VCs and companies, it includes other parties from foundations to individual contributors, from local governments to infrastructure providers. So, can a VC make it "fair" and step back long enough to see all this elements and their motivations and invest accordingly? Well, my answer is clear as I'm not a VC anymore, building developer-centric OSS economy instead.

event.abstract: Open Source Program Offices belong everywhere where open source is used. While it started in companies, we need OSPOs in government, in universities and all over the world. OSPOs help create a contact point, understanding and collaboration for open source to flourish and to be effective. OSPOs at companies act as the first place people inside and outside the company contact to navigate open source questions and policy. They help advocate for open source and to connect the business goals and open source for leadership. event.title: The Open Radio Station: carrier-grade Open Source vRAN hardware - Jean-Paul Smets, Rapid.Space
event.abstract:
The Open Radio Station is a plug-and-play, autonomous 4G/5G base station based on open source hardware. With only 2.4kg and 32W, it provides private networks (industry, police, public safety, etc.) and public networks (mobile coverage extension, fixed wireless). It includes eNodeB/gNodeB, core network, mesh routing, MCPTT, OSS/BSS. All software is open source or licensed source.
We introduce the current hardware design of the ORS (2x1W, 40 Mhz) and how much can be achieved in terms of range (10 km) of number of users (up to 1000). We explain how open source hardware enable three independent supply chains in Europe and Asia.
We then introduce our roadmap towards 2x10W and 100 MHz to cover more use cases. We compare ORS hardware with other initiatives in open telecom.

event.title: How the Silicon Commons, developed through OpenTitan, is revolutionizing chip design - Greg Chadwick, lowRISC, on behalf of the OpenTitan partners
event.abstract:
Creating open-source, industrial quality silicon IP collaboratively is difficult — much harder in fact than for software, due to tooling, supply chain, and manufacturing complexities. The Silicon Commons framework, developed by the OpenTitan partners (lowRISC, Google, Nuvoton, Western Digital, Seagate, Rivos, Winbond, zeroRISC, G+D, ETH Zurich and others) has enabled OpenTitan,— a collaboratively built, secure execution environment and the world’s most active open silicon design – to achieve production-grade readiness.
The Silicon Commons 'managed open' approach explored in this talk covers governance, coding standards, workflow, IP support, design verification, infrastructure, dashboards, documentation, certification processes, and more.

event.title: Opensource code linting for Chip design and verification - Srinivasan Venkataramanan, CEO, AsFigo
event.abstract: In this talk, we present the development and benefits of open-source code linting tools in the realm of chip design and verification. As the complexity of semiconductor designs continues to rise, ensuring code quality and adherence to industry standards becomes a critical factor. The paper presents our recent work on developing an open-source SystemVerilog linter named PySlint based on open-source parser Slang and PySlang. Key aspects such as selection of the implementation platform (Python in our case), integration methodologies, and case studies illustrating successful implementations are explored, providing valuable insights for both industry practitioners and researchers in the field of chip design. Sample rules for SystemVerilog Assertions, DPI, Testbench, and UVM are presented.

event.title: The Inclusive Codebase: Engineering Accessibility in Open Source Software - Ebenezer Don, Principal Developer Advocate, Codegiant, and Olebube Princess Egbuna
event.abstract:
Accessibility often takes a backseat in open source software, creating barriers that exclude a significant portion of users and contributors. This talk spotlights this critical issue, advocating a shift in how we approach open source development.

event.title: A Strategic Approach to Assessing Viability of OSS Projects - Dawn Foster, Director of Data Science, CHAOSS
event.abstract:
The ease in adopting open source can lead to organizations using the software without considering its long-term viability. What happens when a project changes the license, stops making security updates, or has other issues that impact its usage? When a project that is incorporated into your products or services later becomes unviable, it can have negative implications for your users, customers, and reputation.
The presentation contains details about how to assess project policies, governance, security practices, adoption, and community dynamics that can impact the stability and overall viability of a project. The audience will walk away with practical advice about how to strategically evaluate the viability of open source projects and assess the risks and rewards for their situation.

event.title: Digital Public Good: Open Source for Digital Public infrastructure - Michael Schwartz, Founder/CEO, Gluu
event.abstract: The Digital Public Goods Alliance (DPGA) is a UN-endorsed "initiative that facilitates the discovery and deployment of open-source technologies" for digital public infrastructure (DPI) – an underlying network of components such as digital payments, identity, and data exchange systems thare are key to catalyze the UN's 17 Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). Once you've digested that mouthful of acronyms, as an open source enthusiast, you might notice a certain alignment of philosophy: yes... open source software should power our emerging digital society. But this challenge is not for the light-hearted. Even well-funded western governments are not paragons of successful digital transformation. Will the DPGA succeed? What does the UN know about software? And who will pay for it all? This session will cover the following: What is the DPGA? Who is behind it? What are its goals? What is the DPG Registry and the criteria to get listed? What are some successful projects in the Registry that have been successfully deployed by countries? What is the 50-in-5 initiative? What is the Govstack initiative? What are the business incentives for open source projects to participate in the DPGA? What are the unique challenges of accessibility for DPG software? What is the timeframe for action? What are the challenges the DGPA faces? What can you do if you want to get more involved? If the DPGA can provide some of the activation energy to catalyze adoption of open source software by national governments, it would be beneficial for both the public and private sectors to collaborate. The DPGA registration process also brings to light some important considerations regarding the business risks of open source software, and the best practices for long term innovation.

Why do so many organisations still use Java to develop mission critical applications even when it was never designed for microservices or the cloud? Answer: the community!
In this session we’ll dive into how the Java community and open source has reinvigorated this language, exploring community-driven initiatives that continue to ensure Java not only survives, but thrives as a programming language of choice. We’ll cover Java User Groups, community support programs, the development of vendor-agnostic OSS specifications and open-sourced Java frameworks and runtimes. Join this session to see just how powerful the community and OSS can be!

event.title: Wolfi: Building a New Linux (Un)Distribution - Adrian Mouat, Technical Community Advocate, Chainguard
event.abstract:
Chainguard started with a plan to build secure container images. They ended up building a whole new Linux (un)distribution and tooling.
Linux distributions haven't really changed a lot since they were installed via floppy disk. They are designed for a bygone era of local hardware and it's starting to show. Wolfi is a rethinking of what a Linux distribution can be, focused on modern cloud native workloads and containers in particular.
We'll talk about Wolfi's primary use case as a foundation for hardened, up-to-date container images and why existing distributions didn't work for us. We'll explain why we call Wolfi an "undistro" and the underpinning philisophy and technology involved.
Finally, we'll talk about the future, the importance of community and how you can get involved!

event.abstract: In this talk, we present the development and benefits of open-source code linting tools in the realm of chip design and verification. The paper presents our recent work on developing an open-source SystemVerilog linter named PySlint based on open-source parser Slang and PySlang. event.title: Security Scanner Superpowers for Maintainers with OpenVEX! - Adolfo Gracia Veytia, Staff Engineer, Chainguard
event.abstract:
Triaging vulnerabilities can be burdensome for strained open source maintainers and their users. Even more so when false positives make up the bulk of the vulnerability reports!
Enter OpenVEX - a lightweight implementation of the Vulnerability Exploitability eXchange. VEX is a document-based communications channel designed to complement SBOM, enabling maintainers to communicate the effect that a vulnerability has on a piece of software.
With OpenVEX, projects can emit messages, silencing scanner noise and letting users focus on the most important vulnerabilities.
OpenVEX is a project under the Open Source Security Foundation and has support in major vulnerability scanners. In the talk, Adolfo will introduce OpenVEX and its tools with practical use cases across open source.

event.abstract:

Practices such as pinning dependencies, branch protection, required reviews, continuous integration tests etc. are measured to provide a score and accompanying badge.
This presentation will provide a walkthrough of the steps involved in securing a first repository, and then what it takes to repeat that process across and organization with multiple repos. event.title: How do you change the governance model of an established open source project? - Ruth Cheesley, Project Lead, Mautic
event.abstract:
In this talk we delve into the intricacies of reshaping the governance model of an established open source project. This daunting task materialised for Mautic in April 2023 when the project's primary funder and founding company stepped back, enabling it to become fully independent.
The session unpacks the challenges, solutions, and lessons learned from this real-life scenario, providing an insight into how the Mautic community deftly adapted to this shift. event.title: Security Scanner Superpowers for Maintainers with OpenVEX! - Adolfo Gracia Veytia, Staff Engineer, Chainguard
event.abstract:
Triaging vulnerabilities can be burdensome for strained open source maintainers and their users. Even more so when false positives make up the bulk of the vulnerability reports!
Enter OpenVEX - a lightweight implementation of the Vulnerability Exploitability eXchange. VEX is a document-based communications channel designed to complement SBOM, enabling maintainers to communicate the effect that a vulnerability has on a piece of software.
With OpenVEX, projects can emit messages, silencing scanner noise and letting users focus on the most important vulnerabilities.
OpenVEX is a project under the Open Source Security Foundation and has support in major vulnerability scanners. In the talk, Adolfo will introduce OpenVEX and its tools with practical use cases across open source.

event.abstract:
Open Source Security Foundation (OpenSSF) Scorecards provide a way for open source users to determine whether maintainers are being diligent about securing their link in the software security supply chain. Practices such as pinning dependencies, branch protection, required reviews, continuous integration tests etc. are measured to provide a score and accompanying badge.
This presentation will provide a walkthrough of the steps involved in securing a first repository, and then what it takes to repeat that process across and organization with multiple repos. It will also look at the ongoing maintenance involved once scorecards have been implemented, and how aspects of that maintenance can be better automated to minimize toil.

event.title: Digital Public Good: Open Source for Digital Public infrastructure - Michael Schwartz, Founder/CEO, Gluu
event.abstract: The Digital Public Goods Alliance (DPGA) is a UN-endorsed "initiative that facilitates the discovery and deployment of open-source technologies" for digital public infrastructure (DPI) – an underlying network of components such as digital payments, identity, and data exchange systems thare are key to catalyze the UN's 17 Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). Once you've digested that mouthful of acronyms, as an open source enthusiast, you might notice a certain alignment of philosophy: yes... open source software should power our emerging digital society. But this challenge is not for the light-hearted. Even well-funded western governments are not paragons of successful digital transformation. Will the DPGA succeed? What does the UN know about software? And who will pay for it all? This session will cover the following: What is the DPGA? Who is behind it? What are its goals? What is the DPG Registry and the criteria to get listed? What are some successful projects in the Registry that have been successfully deployed by countries? What is the 50-in-5 initiative? What is the Govstack initiative? What are the business incentives for open source projects to participate in the DPGA? What are the unique challenges of accessibility for DPG software? What is the timeframe for action? What are the challenges the DGPA faces? What can you do if you want to get more involved? If the DPGA can provide some of the activation energy to catalyze adoption of open source software by national governments, it would be beneficial for both the public and private sectors to collaborate. The DPGA registration process also brings to light some important considerations regarding the business risks of open source software, and the best practices for long term innovation.

With open source being incorporated into the government's 14th Five-Year Plan in 2021, there was a notable surge in China's open-source ecosystem. However, this growth also brought various challenges, including hurdles in commercializing open-source startups, a lack of metrics for enterprises to gauge their involvement in open source, and internal governance regarding open-source compliance, etc.
In a concise 15-minute talk, the speaker aims to offer a swift overview of the current landscape of open-source development in China, intending to assist those interested in China or aiming to enter the Chinese market to swiftly grasp the evolution of open source within the country.

With the rise of AI and automation, how do we as humans find our value in the workplace? How do we work with these new technologises? How do we build resilience to changes? What skills are needed for us to thrive in this new world?
People have often felt apprehensive about change, especially big changes to the way we work. It happened in the industrial revolution and now it's happening with the rise of artificial intelligence. Five years ago these things existed, but now they are accessible to almost everyone.
In this session I'll cover: - the age of AI - what skills are needed for the "future of work" - working with AI - how we build resilience, problem solving, and critical thinking

event.abstract: As you're building an organization, finding the right people to join is critical. Whether you're hiring a team member or bringing on an advisor, they can be your friend or foe. Knowing how to utilize those advisors is crucial. The right elements will help you scale, while the wrong choices will slow you down. Kelly has spent the past three years leading a nonprofit organization. She has hired and lost a team member, brought on volunteer leaders, and implemented an advisory board. event.title: AI for Developers: Treating Open Source AI as a Function - Martin Hickey, Senior Technical Staff Member, Open Technologies
event.abstract:
More and more apps are being developed which consume AI. AI adoption has more than doubled since 2017 and companies are promoting an AI first strategy. But if a developer wants to consume AI in their applications, do they need to be an AI expert?
In this talk app developers will learn how they can treat AI the same as any other "function". This is made possible by open source AI frameworks that enables users to manage models through dev friendly APIs. Discussion will revolve around open source frameworks like Ray, Triton and TorchServe, to give an understanding of the tools available to help on the AI journey. I'll demo a runtime in action by loading open source models from Hugging Face and querying the models through a web UI.

event.abstract:

There is a tendency to create more obstacles to Linux kernel releases (requiring more approvals etc). But introducing all these obstacles and not treating kernel updates like any other software usually significantly increases the risk for the company and their service of being exploited.

event.abstract:

But the growing success of open source may be putting a unique form of pressure on the existence of OSPOs. In organizations where community best practices are in general use, the need for a large centralized OSPO may be perceived as unnecessary. If everyone knows how open source works, the argument goes, why do you need an OSPO?
In this talk, Red Hat OSPO's Brian Proffitt will describe how even in a mature open source organization, OSPOs are still very necessary, but that their shape might change.

event.title: An engineer's guide to Linux Kernel upgrades - Ignat Korchagin, Cloudflare, Linux Guru
event.abstract:
Because the kernel code executes at the highest privilege level and a kernel bug usually crashes the whole system, many engineers and admins try to avoid upgrading the kernel too often for the sake of stability. There is a tendency to create more obstacles to Linux kernel releases (requiring more approvals etc). But introducing all these obstacles and not treating kernel updates like any other software usually significantly increases the risk for the company and their service of being exploited.
One of the reasons SREs and engineers are afraid of ANY kernel upgrade is that they don’t actually know the details about the Linux kernel release process. This talk tries to demystify Linux Kernel releases and provides a guide on how to distinguish a kernel bugfix release from a feature release.

This data is helping to reduce corruption risks and deliver real-life impacts to prevent and combat corruption, especially when it is structured and can be connected with other BO information and datasets from across the world, and easily exchanged – in other words, when BO data is interoperable. Beneficial ownership transparency brings to light who owns, controls, and benefits from companies and other corporate vehicles (beneficial owners). Beneficial ownership (BO) data is used to investigate corruption and “follow the money”. This data is helping to reduce corruption risks and deliver real-life impacts to prevent and combat corruption, especially when it is structured and can be connected with other BO information and datasets from across the world, and easily exchanged – in other words, when BO data is interoperable. Recognising the power of BOT, over 60 countries now have live BO registers, and at least 20 more countries are working towards launching one. The world is set to generate more BO data than ever before. This presents exciting opportunities as well as practical challenges, namely: How to ensure BO data is used to its fullest potential to prevent and combat transnational corruption?

event.title: CHERIoT: A platform for secure IoT devices - David Chisnall, Director of Systems Architecture, SCI Semiconductor
event.abstract: The CHERIoT Platform is the result of a hardware-software co-design project to build a secure foundation for embedded, connected devices. The project began at Microsoft and is now developed by multiple companies. The core platform includes an open ISA, an open-source core implementing that ISA, and an open-source software stack. With a very small hardware budget, this provides complete memory safety for legacy C/C++ code, and lightweight compartmentalisation that is easy to apply. Commercial silicon is expected in 2024.

event.title: Live hacking your web app: exploiting your open source dependencies - Brian Vermeer, Staff Developer Advocate, Snyk
event.abstract:
Today, almost all software heavily relies on the use of third-party dependencies. While open source modules are undoubtedly awesome, they also represent an undeniable and massive risk. You’re introducing someone else’s code into your system, often with little or no scrutiny. Including the wrong package can introduce severe vulnerabilities, exposing your application and your user’s data.
We’ll look at examples in the wild that have been exposed, some more famously than others, before showing you how to guard against these important security issues.
